race.name: Trough Creek Gravel Grinder
race.tagline: Three distances and family festival vibes through Trough Creek State Park gravel.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Pennsylvania countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Pennsylvania event. Rolling terrain with remote access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Trough Creek Gravel Grinder is a local event in Pennsylvania—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Pennsylvania countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Pennsylvania gravel race. Worth it for Pennsylvania/Northeast riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Pennsylvania—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Pennsylvania races: Dirty Kanza PA, Trans-Sylvania Epic.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Trough Creek area has limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Trough Creek area has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.official_site: Check Trough Creek Gravel Grinder website

course_description.ridewithgps_name: Trough Creek Gravel Grinder - Half Series Route 2025

non_negotiables.why: Pennsylvania rolling terrain requires sustained effort.
Limited organization and remote location require self-sufficiency.

logistics.explanation: Elite racer Evan McGregor describes overthinking 'every decision made leading into race day, every nuance of the course, gear loadout, and so on' during his taper. James Creek location remains 2+ hours from Pittsburgh with no detailed parking or lodging info provided by organizers.

length.explanation: Distance options range from 33.6 to 71.4 miles with the popular Half Series at 40.7 miles. McGregor describes the Half Series as 'around 40 miles and 4000 of elevation' - solid training ride distances without pushing serious endurance boundaries. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: McGregor describes 'a pretty gnarly and technical descent' on trail sections that allowed him to close gaps through superior bike handling. The Half Series mixes 'pavement, gravel, snowmobile trail, doubletrack' but technical features appear limited to specific descent sections. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The Full Series delivers 6,224 feet of climbing over 71.4 miles while the Half Series packs ~4,000 feet into 40 miles. McGregor references 'the longest and hardest climb of the day' where tactical patience proved more valuable than attacking early. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Late September in central Pennsylvania runs 50-70°F typically with fall weather unpredictability. No historical weather incidents mentioned in available race reports, though tire pressure loss during McGregor's race suggests challenging conditions. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Evan McGregor puts it: "The Trough Creek Half Series course is around 40 miles and 4000 of elevation over varied terrain: pavement, gravel, snowmobile trail, doubletrack, it's a great mix!"

altitude.explanation: Trough Creek State Park sits around 1,000-1,500 feet elevation in Pennsylvania hill country. Sea level lungs won't notice any difference - this is low-elevation gravel grinding without mountain altitude training benefits. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The staging area includes 'games, arts, and crafts' for families, creating a festival atmosphere. Three distance options from 33.6 to 71.4 miles let you choose your suffering level through varied Pennsylvania backroads and state park terrain.

prestige.explanation: Part of the Pennsylvania Gravel Series where McGregor needed to win for the overall title, but field sizes of 23-64 riders per category suggest regional rather than national draw. Third year running with limited visibility outside the series.

race_quality.explanation: Chip timing, well-marked course, and fully stocked aid stations hit organizational basics. Cutoff times at 11:00 AM and 12:00 PM for early aid stations provide structure without stress for most riders completing the distances offered.

experience.explanation: Post-race meal, event shirt for early registrants, and Hammer Nutrition samples create solid race-day value. McGregor brings his children to the podium for memories, noting 'There aren't many spouses at the races. There are fewer kids present.'

community.explanation: Family-friendly staging area with activities for children sets it apart from typical gravel races. McGregor emphasizes the family aspect, describing his wife Amanda's presence showing 'hard work, dedication, grit, and excellence' through family support.

field_depth.explanation: Winning times of 2:15:49 for the 41-mile and 3:52:14 for the 71-mile suggest recreational pace rather than elite competition. Field sizes of 23-64 riders per category indicate modest regional participation without national-level depth. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Evan McGregor puts it: "This race highlighted my progression as a performing athlete over the past year... Leading into the race was the longest taper I've ever done of almost two weeks."

value.explanation: Chip timing, aid stations, post-race meal, event shirt, and awards for top three in each category deliver solid infrastructure. Early bird pricing with only $10 increase shows restraint, while family activities add value beyond typical gravel race offerings.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. McGregor's tire pressure dropped 15 psi during his winning race, suggesting technical terrain demands on equipment. James Creek, PA location keeps lodging costs reasonable in rural Pennsylvania, though driving distance from major airports adds travel expense. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Pittsburgh Gravel Route | Gravelcroft
videos.description:
On the outskirts of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania is a gravel biking paradise centered around Cross Creek County Park. The Gravelcroft Route is a 56 mile loop which climbs 5,856 ft of elevation through the history filled Appalachian plateau. Follow me as I crisscross the PA and West Virginia border on beautiful backroads.

A gravel biking alternative to Hillman State Park. I wanted to make a route that had minimum back tracking and no senseless loops upon loops. This route is less than an hour travel time by car from Pittsburgh. 

Download the gravel biking route here. 
https://ridewithgps.com/routes/52131775
https://www.strava.com/routes/3380040846007986134
https://connect.garmin.com/modern/course/364806343

Parking Location
Thompson Hill Park | Thompson Hill Rd, Avella, PA 15312
https://maps.app.goo.gl/a8HWajsFE7ZbeXkf9
videos.transcript:
43 minutes southwest of Pittsburgh is a
lesserknown gravel biking area which
sits between Hillman State Park and the
Whiskey Rebellion routes. Just like the
rest of Pittsburgh's Hinterlands, you
will find a patchwork of gravel and
lightly traveled pavement. Using a
classic adventure mapping software by
National Geographic, I began piecing
together the area's most prominent
gravel roads, creating a 56 mile roller
coaster of a route crisscrossing the
Pennsylvania West Virginia border.
The route climbs almost 6,000 ft through
the heavily dissected Alageney Plateau
and follows the same paths Native
Americans and early European settlers
followed westward. High on the ridges
and low in the wide valleys.
[Music]
[Applause]
The route starts here at Cross Creek
Park in West Middletown. Cross Creek's
gravel goodness is relatively forgotten
about. Some decent gravel segments along
this route only have a handful of
cyclists enjoying them. After this, you
just might rethink Hillman State Park as
Pittsburgh's go-to gravel destination.
After leaving the park, we immediately
enter the ridgetop community of West
Middletown, which was the middle pit
stop for horse and buggy travelers of
the late 1700s. A day's ride from
Washington, Pennsylvania, and the Ohio
River crossing at Wellsburg, West
Virginia.
The early roads of the time followed old
Native American trails along the ridges
to avoid the wet valley bottoms and
ambushes. There were five inns,
blacksmith shops, harness makers, and
other businesses that supported the
trades passing through the town. The
rston grain thrasher was invented and
manufactured here, which prompted Henry
Ford to visit West Middletown to buy one
of the last remaining ones.
Now head down this partially closed road
and down the hill to ALA.
As part of the western frontier, ALA
hosted American frontier men, grist
mills, and refuge forts built by
settlers for protection against Native
American attacks as the area lacked
formal state protection due to the
undefined borders between Pennsylvania
and Virginia. The town's transformation
into a coal mining hub began in the
early 1900s after the completion of the
Wall Bash Railroad. This is what remains
of the Wbash Railroad's connection into
downtown Pittsburgh.
Cole was king in Abella, but it left
scars on the land and blood in the
streets.
One crazy story is that on April 22nd,
1910, drunk Slavic miners crucified
their mind boss named George Rabish, who
was accused of spying on the men for
their breachment of company roles. They
drugg him out of his house twice and
attacked him. On the second time, they
used spikes and rope and left him
hanging for two hours before he was
rescued, but later succumbed to his
injuries.
While traversing this route, there is a
spiderweb of high tension power lines
that loom overhead and gas lines
underneath. From multiple viewpoints,
you'll see the Cardinal plant in Ohio
billowing smoke and steam. AI data
centers are placing a strain on the grid
and reliable electricity is being
summoned from this region again. This
time in the form of natural gas to power
them. Billions are being spent to
convert the decommissioned coal fired
power plants to natural gas for AI. And
our electric bills are still on the
rise.
This road has a legendary name, Shades
of Death Road. As you can imagine, ghost
stories and folklore abound on this
gravel back road.
Zipping down State Line Road towards the
West Virginia border, you'll pass the
Birch Creek Farmer.
To the right on an adjacent hilltop sits
an old relic from the 60s. This AT&T
long lines tower was part of a
cross-country network of microwave
towers that transmitted phone calls,
military comms, and television
broadcasts line of sight using horn
antennas.
The relays became obsolete in the 80s
and 90s when fiber optic technology
emerged.
This tower connected Wheeling to
Alequipa.
All the pavement up until now will be
worth it for this next gravel road in
West Virginia along Amspoker Ridge.
This is one of the best gravel roads
that can be found around here. It has
more of a feeling of riding through
Kansas than West Virginia.
The Amspoker family called this ridge
home since the 1700s.
It is said that Zelma Amspoker attempted
to do everything in her power to
preserve the land of her forefather's
homestead, but eventually lost to the
coal companies who stripped the land.
The area was stripped in the 1950s
before any reclamation laws were
established and stripped again in 2008
and slightly put back together to
normal.
After exiting the strip mine, you
traverse down into the valley and end up
at the map dot of Scott Run.
At the bottom here in Scott Run in 1795,
John Decker was traveling from West
Liberty to Weiron when he stopped to get
a drink from a spring across from the
Wiggins property. Native Americans from
the Mingo tribe shot and sculpted
Decker. Hearing the shots, Tom Wiggins
and others chased the Native Americans
as far as Harman Creek. Decker was
buried here in Scott Run, close by to
where he died. His death is notable
because Decker was the last man in Brook
County, West Virginia, to be killed by
Native Americans.
Fast forward 127 years on July 17th,
1922. A deadly battle took place on the
other side of Cross Creek between
striking miners and mine guards at the
Cliftonville, West Virginia coal mine.
Tensions escalated when the mine
employed non-UN workers. Approximately
300 to 500 armed men marched down the
Walbash railroad from Abella to the mine
where they burned the tipple, killed the
sheriff, and killed eight others.
After this dirt road, you'll head past
the pivotal archaeological site. the
Meadowcraftoft Rock Shelter, which is a
1973 discovery that pushed back
estimates of human habitation in this
part of North America by thousands of
years. The rock shelter was a major
stopover for hunter gatherers who
sheltered under a massive rock overhang,
leaving their presence upon the layers
of soil dating back 19,000 years.
On this back half of the route, you'll
find the most gravel. No matter how you
want to slice a route from Cross Creek,
you'll find a great distance matching
your needs.
Across this bridge is Bethany, West
Virginia. In 1840s, Bethany College was
the first institution of higher
education in West Virginia.
This is also your last chance pit stop
on this route if you need water or
snacks at Chambers General Store only
1,000 ft up the road. Bethany also has
the jazz station WZU 88.1 FM
transmitting above its town.
Okay.
Heat.
This is Dog Run Road, a wilder path with
multiple creek crossings and a
waterfall.
The forests have so much undergrowth
that it limits your sighteline and
hinders any views of sweeping vistas
when climbing.
A bird's eyee view of the topography
does the landscape you're traveling
justice.
Deep under this canopy, you can feel the
struggles of early settlers traversing
the hundreds of similar valleys in the
area.
crossing over Brush Creek again. It's
hard to fathom that this whole area was
going to be flooded for cooling a
minemouth power plant. Back in the 70s,
there was a proposal to take 8,000 acres
in this valley and build a coal plant.
Backbone Road hugs the hillside, leading
you closer to Buckrun Road.
Buckrun Road is another state gamelands
road similar to Dog Run, which is
generally pleasant.
Once you approach the end of the road,
the state and gas companies put down
some super chunky gravel, making it
absolutely brutal.
Once you survive the chunk, you'll hit
the final two gravel roads, Popular and
the farm road of Pawsum Hollow.
What do you do?
As we coast to the end of this gravel
biking adventure, the rich history of
these lands lingers in every pedal
stroke.
These gravel roads, etched with the
stories of settlers, industry, and
resilience have guided us through a
living museum of Pennsylvania's and West
Virginia's past.
Thank you for riding along on this
journey through time and terrain, and I
hope you gained a decent perspective of
what this region close to Pittsburgh has
to offer.

videos.title: Coast to Coast - Pine River Ridge two-track
videos.description: Manistee National Forest, 6.28.17, with Matt Acker
tags: Coast gravel grinder manistee acker mountain bike race

videos.title: Wellsboro Trip
videos.description: Bill and I go for a credit card bicycle tour starting in Jersey Shore, PA to Wellsboro, PA and then back to Jersey Shore.  The total trip is about 120 miles in length.  Most of the milage is on the Pine Creek Rail Trail.

videos.title: Racing my shadow down Vulture Alley segment of the Black Creek Trail. 9-6-2021
videos.description:
Always just out of reach.
Far from a personal best, but I will keep trying.
"vulture alley" is a section that stinks - literally. It starts at Black Point Park & Marina and runs between the canal and the working end of South Miami-Dade's Mount Trashmore to SW 97th Avenue. It is part of the Black Creek Trail. I often ride it up to SW 112th Avenue - across the canal from the South Dade Government Center / Library / Cultural Center.
For the section I ride, the only conflicts with motor vehicle crossings are at 97th Ave, Old Cutler Road, SW 216th Street (a major intersection where you have to negotiate 3 directions of traffic including on / off the Florida Turnpike, and 112th Avenue. 
The Black Creek Trail actually ends at SW 184th Street just West of Zoo Miami / Larry & Penny Thompson Park. 8.7 miles from Black Point to SW 184th Street.

videos.title: Stony (Down) - Allegrippis Trails | Huntingdon, PA
videos.description:
July 9, 2022 - Stony is a trail at Raystown that runs between the Seven Points Road Trailhead and the Baker's Hollow Trailhead. It connects the Northern trail system with the Southern Trail system at Raystown. It flows well from both directions but in this video I rode it from the Baker's Hollow Trailhead (Down). This is in my opinion the most technical trail at Raystown and probably my favorite in either direction.

https://www.trailforks.com/trails/stony/

key_challenges.name: Shades of Death Road
key_challenges.description: A gravel back road with a legendary name where ghost stories and folklore abound.

key_challenges.name: Alageney Plateau
key_challenges.description: Route climbs almost 6,000 ft through the heavily dissected plateau, creating a 56 mile roller coaster of a route.

terrain_notes.text: A patchwork of gravel and lightly traveled pavement, following old Native American trails along the ridges to avoid wet valley bottoms.
Gravel road in West Virginia along Amspoker Ridge described as worth all the pavement riding to reach.

additional_quotes.text: Cross Creek's gravel goodness is relatively forgotten about. Some decent gravel segments along this route only have a handful of cyclists enjoying them.
43 minutes southwest of Pittsburgh is a lesser-known gravel biking area which sits between Hillman State Park and the Whiskey Rebellion routes.

rider_intel.search_text: This gravel route in Pennsylvania covers 56 miles with almost 6,000 feet of climbing through the heavily dissected Alageney Plateau. Starting at Cross Creek Park in West Middletown, the course follows old Native American trails along ridges, featuring a patchwork of gravel and lightly traveled pavement. Key sections include the legendary Shades of Death Road and gravel segments in West Virginia along Amspoker Ridge. The route crosses the Pennsylvania-West Virginia border multiple times and passes through historical areas including former coal mining communities. Located 43 minutes southwest of Pittsburgh, this lesser-known gravel area sits between Hillman State Park and the Whiskey Rebellion routes. Riders describe it as a roller coaster route with relatively forgotten gravel segments that only see a handful of cyclists, making it an alternative to Pittsburgh's more popular gravel destinations.
